deck.name: GCP PCA - Security & Compliance
deck.description: IAM, Compliance, Data protection และ Security best practices สำหรับ GCP Professional Cloud Architect

cards.vocab: How do you design IAM for enterprise organizations?
cards.meaning: ออกแบบ IAM สำหรับ enterprise organizations อย่างไร?
cards.example: IAM hierarchy: Organization → Folders → Projects → Resources. Permissions inherit downward. Design principles: 1) Least privilege: Minimum permissions needed. 2) Separation of duties: No single person has full control. 3) Use groups: Manage permissions via groups, not individuals. 4) Prefer predefined roles: Over primitive (Owner/Editor/Viewer). Role types: 1) Basic (primitive): Owner, Editor, Viewer - too broad. 2) Predefined: Google-defined, granular. 3) Custom: Create for specific needs. Best practices: 1) Cloud Identity for user management. 2) Groups for role assignment. 3) Folders for environment separation. 4) Service accounts for apps, not users. 5) Regular access reviews. Exam tip: Know role hierarchy, when to use custom roles.

cards.vocab: How do you manage service accounts securely?
cards.meaning: จัดการ service accounts อย่างปลอดภัยอย่างไร?
cards.example: Service account types: 1) User-managed: You create and manage. 2) Default: Auto-created (Compute, App Engine) - often over-privileged. 3) Google-managed: For Google services. Best practices: 1) Dedicated SA per service/application. 2) Avoid default service accounts. 3) No user-managed keys when possible. 4) Use attached SA (not key files). 5) Workload Identity for GKE. 6) Short-lived tokens via impersonation. Workload Identity Federation: Allow external workloads (AWS, Azure, on-prem) to use GCP SA without keys. Service account impersonation: User/SA assumes another SA's identity temporarily. Audit: Track SA usage via Cloud Audit Logs. Exam tip: Know Workload Identity, impersonation, avoid key files.

cards.vocab: What are Organization Policies and how do you use them?
cards.meaning: Organization Policies คืออะไร และใช้อย่างไร?
cards.example: Organization Policies: Constraints enforced across organization/folders/projects. Types: 1) Boolean constraints: Enable/disable features. 2) List constraints: Allow/deny specific values. Common policies: 1) compute.vmExternalIpAccess: Restrict external IPs. 2) iam.disableServiceAccountKeyCreation: No SA keys. 3) gcp.resourceLocations: Restrict resource locations. 4) compute.restrictVpcPeering: Control VPC peering. 5) storage.publicAccessPrevention: No public buckets. Hierarchy: Set at org level, can override at folder/project (if allowed). Custom constraints: Create using CEL (Common Expression Language). Use cases: Compliance enforcement, security baseline, cost control. Exam tip: Know common org policies for security, resource location constraints.

cards.vocab: How do you implement data encryption on GCP?
cards.meaning: Implement data encryption บน GCP อย่างไร?
cards.example: Encryption at rest: 1) Google-managed keys: Default, automatic, no config. 2) Customer-managed (CMEK): Keys in Cloud KMS, you control rotation. 3) Customer-supplied (CSEK): You provide keys (limited services). Encryption in transit: 1) Google-managed: Default between GCP services. 2) Customer-managed: TLS certificates, mTLS. Cloud KMS hierarchy: Project → Key Ring → Key → Key Version. Key types: Symmetric (AES-256), Asymmetric (RSA, EC). Cloud EKM: External Key Manager, keys stay outside GCP. Cloud HSM: Hardware Security Module backed keys. Best practices: CMEK for compliance, automate rotation, separate key rings per app. Exam tip: Know CMEK vs CSEK, when to use Cloud HSM/EKM.

cards.vocab: What is VPC Service Controls and how do you use it?
cards.meaning: VPC Service Controls คืออะไร และใช้อย่างไร?
cards.example: VPC Service Controls: API-level security perimeter. Purpose: 1) Prevent data exfiltration. 2) Restrict which networks can access APIs. 3) Compliance requirements. Components: 1) Service perimeter: Boundary around projects/services. 2) Access levels: Conditions for access (IP, identity, device). 3) Ingress/Egress rules: Allow specific cross-perimeter access. How it works: APIs blocked unless within perimeter or allowed by rules. Protected services: BigQuery, Cloud Storage, GCE, etc. Use cases: 1) Prevent accidental public bucket exposure. 2) Restrict data access to corporate network. 3) Meet compliance requirements. Best practices: Start with dry-run mode, use access levels, monitor violations. Exam tip: Know perimeter concepts, ingress/egress rules, dry-run mode.

cards.vocab: How do you design for compliance requirements?
cards.meaning: ออกแบบสำหรับ compliance requirements อย่างไร?
cards.example: Common compliance frameworks: HIPAA (healthcare), PCI-DSS (payments), SOC 2 (security), GDPR (privacy), FedRAMP (government). GCP compliance features: 1) Data residency: Organization policies for resource locations. 2) Access controls: IAM, VPC-SC, BeyondCorp. 3) Encryption: CMEK, Cloud HSM, EKM. 4) Audit: Cloud Audit Logs, Access Transparency. 5) DLP: Cloud DLP for sensitive data discovery. Assured Workloads: Pre-configured environments for compliance (FedRAMP, HIPAA, etc.). Access Transparency: Logs of Google admin access to your data. Data residency: Regional resources, org policies to restrict locations. Best practices: Use Assured Workloads for regulated industries, enable Access Transparency, regular audits. Exam tip: Know GCP compliance offerings, Assured Workloads, data residency controls.

cards.vocab: How do you implement logging and monitoring for security?
cards.meaning: Implement logging และ monitoring สำหรับ security อย่างไร?
cards.example: Audit logging types: 1) Admin Activity: Always on, resource changes (free). 2) Data Access: Read/write data operations (must enable, costs). 3) System Event: GCP system actions. 4) Policy Denied: IAM policy violations. Security monitoring: 1) Security Command Center (SCC): Centralized security dashboard. 2) Event Threat Detection: Detect threats from logs. 3) Container Threat Detection: Runtime threats in GKE. Log export: 1) Cloud Storage: Long-term retention, compliance. 2) BigQuery: Analysis and querying. 3) Pub/Sub: Real-time to SIEM. 4) Splunk, Chronicle: Third-party SIEM. Best practices: Enable data access logs for sensitive resources, export to SIEM, set up alerts for security events. Exam tip: Know audit log types, SCC features, log export destinations.

cards.vocab: What is BeyondCorp and zero-trust security?
cards.meaning: BeyondCorp และ zero-trust security คืออะไร?
cards.example: Zero-trust principles: 1) Never trust, always verify. 2) Access based on identity + context + device. 3) No implicit trust from network location. BeyondCorp Enterprise: Google's zero-trust solution. Components: 1) Identity-Aware Proxy (IAP): Context-aware access to apps. 2) Context-aware access: Conditions (IP, device, time). 3) Endpoint Verification: Device posture checks. 4) BeyondCorp Connector: Access on-prem apps. Implementation: 1) Remove VPN dependency. 2) IAP in front of apps. 3) Access policies based on user + device. 4) Continuous verification. Use cases: Remote workforce, partner access, contractor access, replacing VPN. Exam tip: Know IAP configuration, context-aware access policies, zero-trust vs VPN.
